thread.title: Warren: My Sessions Senate silencing was 'just the beginning'
thread.title_full: Warren: My Sessions Senate silencing was 'just the beginning' | Washington Examiner

author: Anna Giaritelli
title: Warren: My Sessions Senate silencing was 'just the beginning'
text:
Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., followed up Alabama Sen. Jeff Sessions' confirmation as attorney general with a message of defiance to the country's top attorney.
"Deeply disappointed that the Senate confirmed an AG whose record does not show he will faithfully & fairly enforce the law," Warren tweeted immediately after the Senate voted 52-47 to confirm Sessions.
"There's no Rule 19 to silence me from talking about Jeff Sessions anymore. So let me say loudly & clearly: This is just the beginning," Warren wrote, continuing the string of tweets.
"If Jeff Sessions turns a blind eye while @realDonaldTrump violates the Constitution or breaks the law, he'll hear from all of us ... And you better believe every Senator who voted to put Jeff Sessions's radical hatred into @TheJusticeDept will hear from all of us, too ... Consider this MY warning: We won't be silent. We will speak out. And we WILL persist."
Stay abreast of the latest developments from nation's capital and beyond with curated News Alerts from the Washington Examiner news desk and delivered to your inbox.
Sorry, there was a problem processing your email signup. Please try again later. Processing... Thank you for signing up for Washington Examiner News Alerts. You should receive your first alert soon! On Tuesday evening, Senate Republicans voted to block Warren from debating over Sessions' nomination because she broke chamber rules by impugning the motives and conduct of the attorney general nominee, who also happened to be her colleague in the Senate.
Warren had read a letter from Coretta Scott King wrote three decades earlier, alleging Sessions had worked against the intent of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
By Wednesday morning, some claimed Warren's move was an attempt to fundraise off her base and give her more name recognition as a presidential candidate in 2020.
"I'm doing my job," Warren told CNN on Wednesday. "It is my constitutional responsibility to debate Jeff Sessions' confirmation as the attorney general of the United States."
Also from the Washington Examiner Republicans united under Trump, but trade threatens to divide the party "There is a bit of a concern on the trade issue," Mercedes Schlapp said.
By David M. Drucker • 02/09/17 12:17 AM Top Story Democrats scrap all-nighters after DeVos, Sessions votes  thons."
